awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: EAGER: Interaction of carbon-metal nanohybrids at environmental interfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Engineered nanomaterials (NMs) represent a diverse class of extremely small particles (< 100nm) that are being widely used in industrial sectors such as energy, electronics, and sensing.  As these applications demanded higher performance, the field of materials research has shifted its focus from using singular NMs (carbon only, metal only) to those comprised of several distinct types of NMs linked together, termed nanohybrids (NHs). Linking single NMs in this capacity is likely to create new properties and behavior in environmental and biological settings that have not yet been predicted or studied. As the scale of NH use rapidly increases there is likely to be significant opportunity for their presence in the aquatic environment. Therefore, the goal of this proposed work is to proactively identify novel and unanticipated properties and associated behavior of carbon-metal NHs that have current relevance to the fuel cell industry. These studies would be the first to investigate whether combining singular NMs to form NHs alters the way they behave in the environment and interact with aquatic organisms. 

Extracting novel properties by developing ensembles of two or more nano-scale materials is an emerging trend in several industries. However, most of our knowledge regarding nano-environmental behavior is limited to passive nanostructures with singular composition (e.g. carbon, metal). We hypothesize that NHs will display novel unforeseen properties that are highly important in driving their behavior in environmental matrices and organisms. To address this notion we propose to carry out the following aims: (1) synthesize a set of metal-carbon nanotube NHs with high degree of control with the objective of tuning band architecture and material stiffness; (2) characterize physical morphology, mechanical stiffness, band gap, distribution of metal/metal oxides on nanotubes; (3) examine NH interaction with the environmental interfaces by studying particle-particle and particle-collector interaction as well as determining particle dissolution in a wide range of environmental conditions; (4) assess behavior and interaction of NHs at biological interfaces using a well-established aquatic model coupled with high-throughput contemporary measurements of mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative stress. This work is innovative in that it is the first to execute controlled synthesis and characterization of a suite of NHs and component materials that will be investigated in aquatic environments and model organisms (fish). This work is timely in that it will lay the foundation for further research in understanding NHs in complex but relevant environments and reveal novel properties and mechanisms of action in biological systems that have not been studied. 

The proposed work will generate critical and fundamental knowledge to better understand the environmental interaction of a set of complex hierarchical nanomaterials, metal-carbonaceous NHs.  These NHs are highly relevant to the expanding fuel cell industry; therefore, results of this work would directly influence materials science and nano communities and help inform the general public about nano-environmental research. In outreach and education aspects the PIs will recruit undergraduate researchers, including underrepresented students, through several well established programs at UT and UF such as Graduates Linked with Undergraduates in Engineering (GLUE) program, Texas Research Experience (TREX) program, Florida-Georgia Alliance for Minority Participation (FGAMP-SEAGEP) and Howard Hughes Medical Institute (HHMI) Science for Life programs to recruit minority students.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Ensembles of two or more pre-synthesized nanomaterials, termed nanohybrids (NHs), are engineered to extract unique functions through alteration of their properties. Though the use of these composite materials are beneficial and are utilized in numerous commercial applications, their environmental impacts need to be evaluated for safe use. The main goal of this project is to synthesize, characterize, and assess environmental interaction of carbonaceous-metal oxide NHs; in particular we examined the aggregation, transport, and biological interaction (with fish and cells) of these NHs and their components.  This project resulted in 4 peer-reviewed journal articles and 1 book chapter while trained. 3 graduate and 2 undergraduate students at the University of Texas and also 2 graduate students, 2 undergraduate students, and 1 high school student at the University of Florida on nanomaterial synthesis, characterization, and environmental behavior assessment. The findings of the project were disseminated via 13 national and international conference presentations.  

Intellectual Merit:

In this project, zero-valent metal and metal oxide nanocrystals were formed on multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWNTs) using a modified sol-gel method. The mechanism of formation was enumerated with standard electrode potentials of the parent metal species. One of the most used NHs, i.e., MWNT-TiO2, have been synthesized for a range of C:Ti ratios. Detailed material characterization has been performed to assess physical and chemical properties of the synthesized materials; these materials were then utilized to assess their environmental behavior.

The aggregation results indicate that MWNT-TiO2 hybrid nanomaterial aggregation may not be captured by the aggregation behavior of its components (i.e., MWNTs and TiO2). The evidence of lowest stability (or highest aggregation propensity) of NHs with C:Ti molar ratio of 1:0.1 compared to relatively more stable and with comparable stability for C:Ti molar ratio of 1:0.05 and 1:0.033, demonstrate that behavior of the NHs may not be captured by the behavior of the components only; rather local surface roughness and patchiness on the surface that generate from hybridization will also contribute to NH behavior alteration. Similarly, the transport results show that hybrid nanomaterial mobility is substantially different than its component MWNTs. Particle-particle interaction is likely favored over particle-collector interaction, which can lead to pore-blocking and also to larger ‘mass’ of particle elution.

The biological exposure results indicate that the nanomaterials tested, including the MWNT-TiO2 NHs, do not have a significant effect on lethality and growth of fish larvae in acute exposure scenarios (96 h exposure). This is likely due to the lack of stability of such materials and therefore, water exposure is not likely the most relevant exposure route. Hybridization appears to have a significant impact on cellular ROS production and gene expression in multiple cell types (human and fish). Interestingly, greater loads of TiO2 (30:1) result in the least amount of ROS produced. Phototransformation decreases the ROS production for the NHs, while increasing the same for component MWNTs. Furthermore, results suggest that specific responses of the mitochondria to stress are altered without concomitant drain on energy reserve. This points to autophagy as a mechanism of mitochondrial function that may be stimuated.

The environmental and biological interaction results obtained in this study indicate that the behavior of the whole (i.e., hybrid) is uniquely different from the sum of its parts (i.e., its components). It is to be noted that such conclusion may apply to other carbonaceous-metal/metal oxide hybrids that introduce similar surface complexity and local heterogeneity. The validity of this conclusion and possible generalization for carbon-metal hybrids with other metal types and for other hybrid families (i.e., carbon-carbon, metal-metal, or metal-ligand types) should be contingent upon further studies on those materials.

Broader Impacts: 

Linking single nanomaterials to generate complex nanohybrids (NHs) is likely to create new properties and behavior in environmental and biological settings that have not yet been predicted or studied utilizing singular and passive nanostructures. As the scale of NH use rapidly increases there is likely to be significant opportunity for their presence in the aquatic environment. Thus it is imperative to assess the importance of studying these composite multicomponent materials’ behavior in the environment and to probe the ‘part-whole’ question. The overall outcome of the project is a potentially consequential conclusion; i.e., the behavior of the whole (i.e., hybrid) is uniquely different from the sum of its parts (i.e., its components). This conclusion identifies this area of research to be of fundamental importance in nanomaterials safety assessment. However, the validity of this conclusion against the entire class of nanohybrids is dependent on future systematic studies.

 

Furthermore, several students, including undergraduate, graduate and high school students gained training as part of this project, several through programs for underrepresented students. These students participated in dissemination of the work through publications and presentations at conferences, gaining mentorship and cross training in a novel and highly relevant area that is of immediate and critical importance to our society. 

 


Last Modified: 08/29/2018
Modified by: Navid Saleh
